name: Tours
fun_fact: Fun fact: Tours was awarded the title 'International City of Gastronomy' and produces 80% of France's goat cheese - the Loire Valley's chalky soil creates the perfect terroir for both wine grapes and grazing goats.

hero_dishes.name: Rillettes de Tours
hero_dishes.description: Luxuriously rich pork spread cooked slowly in fat for 6-12 hours, creating a rustic p√¢t√© with incredible depth
hero_dishes.origin_story: This IGP-certified specialty (protected since 2013) was born from Loire Valley frugality - slow-cooking tough pork cuts in their own fat preserved meat before refrigeration. Tours perfected the technique, and now hosts an annual festival celebrating this beloved spread.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Covered market in central Tours (38 stalls with regional specialties), local charcuteries throughout the city, troglodyte cave restaurants near Amboise and Saumur

hero_dishes.name: Sainte-Maure-de-Touraine Goat Cheese
hero_dishes.description: Soft log-shaped goat cheese with a distinctive straw running through its center, covered in edible ash
hero_dishes.origin_story: Dating back to the 8th century, this PDO cheese from the Loire Valley is one of five protected goat cheeses from the region. The straw through the middle isn't decorative - it supports the delicate cheese and bears the producer's mark of authenticity.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Loches market (Wednesday and Saturday - over 100 stallholders), Amboise Sunday riverside market, goat cheese farms south of Chinon (with tours and wine pairings)

hero_dishes.name: Fou√©es
hero_dishes.description: Warm, hollow flatbreads that puff up when baked, sliced open and stuffed with rillettes, goat cheese, or garlic butter
hero_dishes.origin_story: These traditional breads were baked in wood-fired ovens to test the temperature before the main bread. Locals discovered they made perfect edible pockets for leftovers. Now served in atmospheric troglodyte cave restaurants carved into limestone cliffs.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Troglodyte cave restaurants near Amboise, Tours, Saumur, and Angers - dining in 16th-century refuges from the Wars of Religion

signature_drinks.name: Loire Valley Wines
signature_drinks.description: Crisp Sancerre, Chinon reds, and sparkling Vouvray from the 'Garden of France'
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Paired meticulously with local dishes - Sancerre with goat cheese, Chinon red with rillettes. Wine bars in Tours pour by the glass from hundreds of local producers. The chalky tuffeau soil creates distinctive minerality.

signature_drinks.name: Cointreau
signature_drinks.description: Crystal-clear orange liqueur invented in nearby Angers, perfumed with sweet and bitter orange peels
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Enjoyed as a digestif after meals or in cocktails. The distillery in nearby Saint-Barth√©lemy-d'Anjou offers tours. Locals appreciate its creation story - Edouard Cointreau perfected the recipe in 1875.

food_culture_notes: Tours' covered market (Les Halles) offers weekly cooking demonstrations teaching regional classics like rillettes and fou√©es
The Loire Valley's long growing season and mineral-rich soil produce exceptional vegetables, wild herbs, and berries
Rillons (pork belly chunks) belong to the 'Touraine Brotherhood of Rillons and Rillettes' - a culinary guild protecting traditions
Troglodyte restaurants are carved into the region's soft limestone cliffs - diners eat in caves that once sheltered religious refugees
